Mother Theodore Guerin was a woman in frequent conflict with the hierarchy of her church.
Commentator Peter Manseau.
In her lifetime, she was dismissed from her religious vows, banished from her order, even threatened with excommunication.
Now she's a saint?
This is nothing new.
The Catholic Church has had plenty of practice turning its heretics into its holiest.
The most famous example would be Joan of Arc, for whom sainthood came by way of a burning at the stake.
It seems sometimes that where faith is concerned, yesterday's heresy is today's orthodoxy.
I wonder what future generations will make of those who are thorns in the side of religious authority today.
For me, this question is far from academic.
My father was an excommunicated Roman Catholic priest.
In fact, when I was growing up, most of the fathers in my parents' circle were priests without parishes.
Many of the mothers were former nuns, like my mother.
They had all married in the late 1960s.
It was a failed attempt to change their Church's policy of mandatory celibacy for clergy.
As a result, they were ejected from the official ranks of the faithful.
But they have never given up the faith.
My siblings and I used to call them the married priest people.
They gathered regularly at our house to celebrate mass in our dining room.
Then we'd cook hamburgers, play badminton and do all the things non-excommunicated families do at summer weekend get togethers.
At the time, I had no idea of the significance of these homey affairs.
But now I see them as what they were, the backyard barbecue a suburban heretics convention.
Dad lived for these occasions.
All through the year, his vestments hung in dry cleaning bags in the front hall closet, like an injured athlete's uniform.
He was always ready to get back in the game.
The religious lives my parents had once had were mysterious to me.
But I did know that like Mother Guerin, they'd been banished from the community they loved.
They believed that the Church would catch up to their radical ideas.
It seemed like blind faith to me.
Yet seeing now what has become of this nearly excommunicated nun turned saint, I don't think this will be the final chapter of my parents' story.
History may indeed be written by the winners, but it is revised by the patient, the stubborn, those who insist that words like excommunication or banishment don't mean an end, but a beginning.
That's how it always felt to me when the married priest people gathered.

With two dozen of us crammed around a dining room table, my father would stand in what seemed his natural state - white vestments, gold stole, presiding over a mass made of improvised liturgical elements.
A ceramic chalice filled with pink zinfandel, a dinner plate piled with pita bread.
After scripture readings and a short sermon, my father lifted the plate.
This is my body.
He lifted the cup.
This is my blood.
And then both were passed around the table from priest to nun to child.
Of course, as a good Catholic of the 19th Century, Mother Guerin probably would've been scandalized by such a scene.
As her own story shows us though, today's rule breakers just might be tomorrow's saints.

In the early '80s, the singing group DeBarge became one of the last big R&B acts of the original Motown label.
Mark, James, Randy and Eldra, plus their sister Bunny, were the original line-up of the band DeBarge.
But these hit-makers were only a fraction of a large and troubled music-making family.
Motown made another group of siblings, the Jackson Five, legends.
But even with the Motown touch, DeBarge struggled with fame.
As the members were singing feel good hits, they were also dealing with drug addiction, sexual abuse, prison and HIV.

A new television documentary on the DeBarge family airs later this month on TV One as part of a series called ""Unsung."" Bunny DeBarge agreed to tell us her part of the story, and why she wants to share it with the world.
Because I believe there's a lot of people out there that might have been through the same thing that I've been through.
I also believe that secrets keep you sick.
My family is in need of healing, and I feel that it has caused a lot of hurt and pain and has been part of our drug problems, things that have happened in our childhood.
And there were things that I thought I had to face, and I feel this is the time.
It was a lot of healing for me, and I want my father to be healed and my mother to be healed as well as my brothers to be healed.
And I also want the next generation to understand why we went through what we went through in life, period.
I am such a fan of your songs, and they really were for me a form of escapism.
And they're about love and they're very - love and having fun and they're very lighthearted in a lot of ways, and tender.

What was it like to do songs that were so tender, and yet at the same time you were going through, like you mentioned, addiction, and your brothers and sisters were fighting, there was jockeying for power?
What was it like to have this one world of music that really made so many people happy, and at the same time you were struggling?
We weren't struggling then.
When we were writing our love songs - we weren't struggling.
